As a retired researcher, If you take a closer look at the so-called "groundbreaking" research coming out of Harvard over the past decade, funded by nearly $90 billion in taxpayer money, you'll find a very different story than the one presented in press releases. None of these discoveries came out of Harvard in isolation. Theyâ€™re all extensions, optimizations, or repackagings of work that has been underway globally for decades.

CRISPR? Thatâ€™s built on a bacterial immune mechanism discovered in the late '80s, refined by researchers around the world. Harvard was one of many institutions involved, not the origin.

Prime editing? Just a more precise spin on CRISPR, which itself is part of a longer lineage of gene-editing tools.

Flow batteries? Theyâ€™ve been around for over 50 years. Harvardâ€™s version is just a tweak in chemistry for better stability: not a new invention.

The truth is, academic research, especially at elite institutions is rarely the source of isolated breakthroughs. It's a web of collaboration, and Harvard often plays the role of amplifier rather than originator. Itâ€™s well-positioned to secure grants, license patents, and dominate headlines, but that doesnâ€™t mean the work is fundamentally new.

And letâ€™s be honest: the grant game incentivizes incrementalism, buzzwords, and safe bets with publishable results, not genuine risk or paradigm-shifting discovery. Institutions that thrive off massive federal grants often operate more like publicly subsidized private enterprises.. filtering taxpayer money through a prestige machine that spits out white papers, paywalled publications, and eventual commercialization for private gain.

Call it what it is: a polished, institutionalized pipeline where the public funds the research, but rarely sees the return.
